clinicaldetails.diagnosis: Renal Bx: Probable FSGS but minimal glomerular scarring
Interstial nephritis also seen ? mesalazine related

letter.lettercontent:
FOLLOW UP: 22nd February 2006
I reviewed this gentleman in the Renal Clinic on the 15th February following his very recent discharge from the Ward. I doubt that you have had full communication regarding this so in brief, he was admitted to the RIE on the 31st January with clinical and biochemical nephrotic syndrome. His oedema had been increasing for at least 2 weeks and he was noted on the 24th January in a Clinic to have an albumin of 17. 24 hour urine collection demonstrated 20g of proteinuria.
He has a past history of asthma but has not needed inhalers for 10 years. He was at the time of admission taking Mesalazine 1.6g tds for ulcerative colitis.
He was admitted to the Renal Ward and a renal biopsy was performed on the 2nd February. Whilst this only had 3 glomeruli, this did show features compatible with FSGS although with minimal glomerular or interstitial scarring or tubular atrophy. Additionally there was an eosinophilic interstitial infiltrate that is likely to be unrelated to the glomerular disease and it was felt most likely to be due to the Mesalazine.
His Mesalazine was therefore discontinued and he was commenced on 60mg a day of Prednisolone with the plan being for this to continue for 8 weeks or until resolution of his nephrotic syndrome, whatever should come first.
Because of the Prednisolone dose he was also commenced on Omeprazole and Fosamax and Calcichew for bone protection.
His fluid retention was treated with Frusemide. He initially required 160mg a day with additional Bendrofluazide but it was clear by discharge that this could be reduced because of a major diuresis and rising albumin. Already by the 7th February having been on steroids for less than a week, his 24 hour urinary protein had halved to 11.6g. Because of this improvement after discussion with the patient, we elected not to anti-coagulate because he was firstly very active and secondly we had good reason to hope that the nephrotic syndrome would resolve quickly. The risks of anti-coagulation were therefore thought to outweigh the benefits.
He was discharged on the 9th at which point his albumin was 21g/L (nadir 13 on the 2nd February). On return to Clinic he has been very well and has continued to gently lose weight at the rate of about 1kg a day. On our Clinic scales he was 97.3kg. On admission to the Renal Ward for comparison, he was 115.8kg. He is now down to 80mg of Frusemide a day and is carrying clearly much less excess fluid.
Very encouragingly and in keeping with his reduced requirement for diuretic, his albumin has risen to 28g/L and his 24 hour urinary protein is down below 1g. He is clearly therefore very steroid sensitive.
I would plan to wait until complete resolution of proteinuria before starting to wean his steroids but I suspect this will be soon. I have arranged to see him weekly for the time being for review as he will need some fairly major dose titrations of a lot of his drugs as his clinical situation improves.
Kind regards.

FOLLOW UP: 8th March 2006 - Dr Goddard's Renal Clinic
I reviewed this gentleman in the Renal Clinic on the 22nd February.
He has been on Prednisolone since the 3rd and now has a normal serum albumin and not only no proteinuria on a 24 hour urine collection, but has a normal albumin and creatinine ratio at 2.6mcg/mmol. This is obviously an excellent response. Renal function remains normal and he now has no excess fluid. I have suggested therefore he stop his Frusemide.
In respect of the steroids, I have suggested continuing for a further 1 week and 2 days to make 4 weeks a total of 60mg and then reduce to 45mg for a week, 30mg for a week by which time we will have reviewed him again in Clinic. I have also given him some urine dipsticks to test his own urine intermittently should there be any suggestion of any reoccurrence.
Inkeeping with the resolution of his product syndrome, his cholesterol is now falling. At it's peak it was 9.4mmol/L and is now 7.9mmol/L and we would expect this to improve further as he moves further out from this illness. I have arranged to see him again in 2 weeks.
Kind regards.

FOLLOW UP: 5th April 2006 - Dr Goddard's Renal Clinic
RECOMMENDED CHANGES TO TREATMENT:
Patient was advised to reduce Prednisolone further down to 30mg daily for 2 weeks and then down to 25mg od.
I saw this gentleman in the Renal Clinic on the 8th March.
He seems to be experiencing a lot of side effects related to the high dose steroids. He particularly complained of shaky hands, insomnia, muscle cramps, general lethargy and an altered taste in his mouth. He had been to the dentist who decided to take an x-ray of his jaw and found that he had lost a lot of bone mass.
He told me of diarrhoea and vomiting that had occurred the previous week whereby Frusemide and Lisinopril had been discontinued briefly. Within a short space of time he managed to gain about 4«kg of weight and has since re-started Frusemide and Lisinopril.
Examination revealed no peripheral oedema and blood pressure was very reasonable.
On dipstick testing his urine was negative for protein and there was no protein in his 24-hour urine collection either. Renal function tests remained normal and he is slightly hyper filtrating with a creatinine clearance of 149mls/min. Urinary volume is 2.7L and he has a fairly high amount still with sodium in it of 280mmol. He tells me he is taking predominantly fruits and that he is not taking too much salt.
Despite the fact that her serum albumin had risen to 44mmol/L, his cholesterol level remains elevated at 7.1.

FOLLOW UP: 5th April 2006 - Dr Goddard's Renal Clinic
I reviewed this gentleman in the Renal Clinic on the 22nd March 2006.
His nephrotic syndrome remains in remission. His urine dipstick in Clinic showed + protein but these are notoriously sensitive and his formal 24 hour urine demonstrated that his protein was below the laboratory detection limit. Consistent with the resolution of his nephrotic syndrome, his albumin is now completely normal at 40g/L and his cholesterol has fallen dramatically from a peak of 9.4 down to 5.3mmol/L on this occasion.
We have agreed that he should reduce his Prednisolone down to 20mg this week and remain at that level until reviewed in 2 weeks when we will continue slow weaning. Mr Sharif raised a deep dull ache on the left side which on examination was more anterior. He has had no dysuria, fevers or shivers and had no renal tenderness and I am pleased that his MSU was also negative both for red and white cells. I have reassured him in Clinic that I don't think this is related to his kidneys. He is taking a small amount of Frusemide a day to remain oedema free. Given his serum albumin is now normal he should hopefully not need this for too much longer.
I have been a little remiss in spotting that his MCV is low at 73. I will ensure he has iron studies done on his next visit and also haemoglobin and electrophoresis, as a thalassaemia trait might also explain this.
Finally he has an appointment to see Dr MacGilchrist in respect of his ulcerative colitis and treatment thereof on the 9th May.
Kind regards.

FOLLOW UP: 1 month RECOMMENDED CHANGES TO TREATMENT:
I reviewed this gentleman in the Renal Clinic on the 5th of April. From the point of view of his nephrotic syndrome, this remains in complete remission with an ACR of less than 1, serum albumin 40.
Mr Sharif had phoned me during the week because last Sunday he had spots in front of his eyes and checked his blood pressure with a relative's machine, which read 58/36. We therefore discontinued his Furosemide and Lisinopril and he has been fine since and blood pressure in clinic was 138/82. I have instructed him to reduce his Prednisolone to 17.5mg for two weeks and then 15mg for two weeks and we will see him in a month.
However, the slight concern is his haemoglobin and iron status. On his last letter you will recall that I noted that his MCV was low at 73. Mr Sharif confirmed that he has been repeatedly checked for thalassaemia trait, as his wife does have this and it obviously has implications with the children. He is negative. I have not therefore re-checked this on this occasion. However, you will see from the attached letter that his haemoglobin has been falling. It was 123 at the beginning of March, 102 at the end and 86 now. In keeping with this, his ferritin is 6 and iron less than 3. The most obvious therefore, would be GI bleeding and I do wonder if the event last Sunday was something a little more acute. However, he does not give any history compatible with melaena.
In the first instance, I would be grateful if you could prescribe Ferrous sulphate for him. He is already on 40mg of Omeprazole and I will arrange an urgent endoscopy.
Interestingly, while I said steroids will potentially be an issue in terms of gastric irritation, I do note that his MCV on presentation to us before ever being treated was 75. The other option for GI blood loss was of course his ulcerative colitis, but again this is currently clinically not causing problems.
Kind regards,
Yours sincerely,
Dr J Goddard Consultant Renal Physician
cc. Mr Tabassum Sharif Dr Alastair MacGilchrist, Consultant Gastroenterologist, RIE

FOLLOW UP: 26/07/2006 RECOMMENDED CHANGES TO TREATMENT: Prednisolone to increase back up to 40mg for 2 weeks and then reduce to 30mg if proteinuria resolves.
This gentleman was seen in the Renal Clinic on 28 June. He had contacted me at the beginning of the week to say he had proteinuria again on urine dipstick and indeed he has had a recurrence of his nephrotic syndrome with a spot urine showing 13.5gms/l proteinuria and his albumin having fallen down to 31gms/l. Hopefully we have caught this however relatively early given his vigilance and I have advised him to increase his Prednisolone up to 40mg for 2 weeks. If his proteinuria becomes negative (he has dipsticks at home and knows how to use them) he should then reduce to 30mg for 2 weeks and we will see him in 4 weeks. If he is still positive he should stay at the 40mg.
He was previously very steroid sensitive and it may be that we are dealing with steroid sensitive but relapsing nephrotic syndrome, however only a further reduction in Prednisolone will tell us this.
I understand also that the GI Physicians are happy for him to have no additional treatment for his ulcerative colitis providing he remains on more than 1.5mg Prednisolone. We will also need to consider this in our weaning policies.
In respect of other issues his haemoglobin has come back up to 118gms/l having had a dose of intravenous iron (CosmoFer) in May. His ferritin is now 263 as opposed to unrecordable before the transfusion!
I have arranged to see Mr Sharif in 4 weeks in clinic but he has my e-mail to contact me if there are further issues in the interim.
Kind regards.
Yours sincerely,
Dr J Goddard Consultant Renal Physician
